title: U.S. Interest Rates Are Rising In Relative Terms Too
text: The rise in US interest rates is refocusing minds and prompting attitude adjustments the world over, but most of the attention has been on the absolute increases in yields. As the premium in US interest rates rises, the effects ripple out into the global economy on multiple fronts.

title: 'Foot Traffic' Recession Continues To Weigh On Small Business Sentiment
text: The small-business-optimism index from the National Federation of Independent Business rose 0.8 points to 95.8 in February. Within the details of the small business survey, the net percentage of respondents expecting better economic conditions ("better" minus "worse") rose to -19 in February versus -23 in January.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Make Further Progress Towards November Lows
text: This week, on a unadjusted basis, new jobless claims increased by 31,519 to 748,078. Seasonally adjusted claims increased by 9,000 to 745,000. The recent increase in claims appears to have subsided. Nevertheless both adjusted and unadjusted claims remain above their worst levels at the depths of the Great Recession.

title: I wouldn't sleep on growth stocks, structural growth stocks will be long term winners: Strategist
text: Invesco Global Market Strategist Brian Levitt discusses inflation, the Fed and the the outlook for the stock market.

title: Cyclical Tech Stocks Have Momentum, Medley Global Says
text: Mar.09 -- Ben Emons, managing director of global macro strategy at Medley Global Advisors, discusses the outlook for U.S. Treasuries, stocks and Federal Reserve policy. He speaks with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts on "Bloomberg Daybreak: Asia.

title: 'Pennies: Going In Raw' Recap: Market Sell-Off… What Now?
text: Last week, many traders who got started within the past year saw something they had never seen before: multiple red days in a row. In their latest episode, "Pennies: Going In Raw" hosts Hugh Henne and Dan Knight discussed different ways for individual investors to protect their portfolios and find opportunities at the same time.

title: Market bull Jeremy Siegel warns the Nasdaq rebound will unravel, favors value stocks
text: The economic backdrop dramatically supports the reopening trade over Big Tech and growth plays, according to Wharton's Jeremy Siegel.

title: Bond Market Is Unstable
text: The $1.9 trillion fiscal stimulus bill that is being passed by the U.S. Congress will create a new economic environment, one that may cause changes in Federal Reserve policies. Over the past decade and especially within the current disrupted environment, the Federal Reserve has been a constant support to the economy and to the stock market.

title: Tech Stocks Lead a Market Rebound Tuesday
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 31,832.74 on Tuesday with a gain of 30.30 points or 0.10%. The S&P 500 closed at 3,875.44 for a gain of 54.09 points or 1.42%.

title: Markets Up Tuesday, but Off Session Highs
text: The tech-heavy index, which had been trading more that +500 points during the intraday, closed +3.7% or 465 points. It was led by a 19% gain in Tesla (TSLA).

title: Nasdaq Makes Its Biggest Gain Since Nov. 4; Is The Stock Market Ready To Remove Its Bearish Stripes?
text: The Nasdaq posted its biggest gain since November. Is Tuesday's market bounce for real?

"We took a little money off the table on tech a couple of months ago, we're comfortable with that," Wren said.

title: The Dow Rose 30 Points Because Big Tech Roared Back
text: Investors bought the dip in growth stocks as rates retreated, and Big Tech banner names including Tesla and Amazon were big beneficiaries.

title: Stock Market Today: Nasdaq Scores Biggest Surge in 4 Months
text: Tesla, Apple and a most other large-cap tech names triggered a relief rally in the Nasdaq a day after the index fell into correction.

title: Bond yield settling allows for broad market rally but Dow gets shaky before the close
text: 4:20pm: DJIA takes a late dive but stays positive The Dow ended Tuesday up 30 points, 0.1%, at 31,833. The index tumbled in the final hurs of trading after being up about 350 around midday.

title: Inflation may have been warming up in February, but it could be hot by May
text: Inflation is just warming up, but by late spring it could get downright hot, even if just temporarily.

title: Pouring $1.9T stimulus into economy carries risk of inflation: Kelly
text: JPMorgan chief global strategist David Kelly discusses the impact the $1.9T COVID stimulus bill and higher wages may have on inflation. Subscribe to Fox Business!

title: Nasdaq soars 4% as technology stocks rebound on decline in bond yields
text: The Nasdaq 100 had its best trading session since April 2020, surging more than 3.7% after entering correction territory on Monday. The Nasdaq 100 was down more than 10% from its mid-February high on Monday. High-growth tech stocks have been extra volatile as movements in bond yields continued to have an outsized influence on the sector.

title: U.S. stocks finish higher as tech rebounds; Nasdaq jumps 3.7%
text: U.S. stocks finish higher as tech rebounds; Nasdaq jumps 3.7%

title: Tech bounces back — Here's what analysts say investors should watch
text: Tech stocks led a market rally on Tuesday as bond yields declined. Here's what market experts say about the move.

title: Jared Bernstein on whether the stimulus bill will boost inflation
text: Jared Bernstein, President Biden's Council of Economic Advisors member, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the relief bill, the state of the coronavirus stimulus checks and the U.S. economy.

title: The Fed needs to convince stock investors that their rate hike expectations are priced in 'too aggressively', Barclays says
text: The Federal Reserve will likely keep working to convince equity investors that expectations are being priced in "too aggressively" for when the central bank will start raising interest rates and how fast those changes will occur, according to the US head of stock trading at Barclays. The Fed's two-day meeting starting on March 16 will be held at a time of notable rotations in equity markets, spurred in part the quick rise in borrowing rates this year as tracked by some Treasury yields. Yields have pushed higher in part as investors anticipate a rise in inflation as the US economy recovers from the COVID-19 health crisis.

title: There are secular reasons to like semiconductors, says Russ Koesterich
text: Russ Koesterich, BlackRock Global Allocation Fund portfolio manager, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss how BlackRock is shifting its portfolio and the opportunities he's seeing in the market.

title: AllianceBernstein's Grant: Opportunities in consumer discretionary, skeptical on energy
text: Mar.09 -- AllianceBernstein Senior Portfolio Manager Valerie Grant says investors should stay relatively balanced during the current rotation from growth to value. Grant sees opportunities in industrials, financials and consumer discretionary but bearish on energy stocks, saying it will be difficult to forecast cash flows for oil and gas companies going forward.

title: Technically Speaking: The Bull Market Is On Shaky Ground
text: The big question for investors at the moment is whether the 11-year old bull market is ending or is this just a “pause that refreshes?”.

title: Tech stocks rebound as Nasdaq jumps over 3 percent
text: US stocks advanced on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq jumping over 3 percent to recoup its losses in the previous session as US bond yields retreated and investors picked up battered technology stocks. Among the biggest boosts to the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq were Tesla, Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft, jumping between 2.4 percent and.

text: Convention has it that "capital flows" are determined by the portfolio effects of interest rate differentials.

text: Yahoo Finance's Aikiko Fujita and Zack Guzman spoke to Harding Loevner Portfolio Manager Chris Mack about the tech rebound.

title: The Equity-Gold Price Conundrum - Part I
text: The relentless rally in equity markets has pushed valuations to extreme levels based on traditional metrics. In this report, we analyze the two common arguments made by equity bulls on why this time is different and current valuations are justified.

title: Tech trade isn't over, but adjustment was needed: Mike Wilson
text: CNBC's "Halftime Report" team discusses the tech trade and the market movers with Mike Wilson, chief U.S. equity strategist at Morgan Stanley.

title: Is This Time is Different?
text: “This Time is Different” is an infamous phrase in finance that has historically led to some spectacular results, both positively and negatively. Over the past ten years in the United States, the information technology sector (“TECH”) of the equity market has outperformed all other equity market sectors by a significant margin[1].

title: The Technical Indicator: Charting a bullish reversal: Nasdaq ventures atop the breakdown point
text: Technically speaking, the S&P 500 and Dow industrials have retained a bullish intermediate-term bias — even amid recent volatility — while the Nasdaq Composite is vying to repair a more damaging March downdraft, writes Michael Ashbaugh.

title: Recent stock market weakness represents a rotational correction rather than a big top, BofA says
text: A correction in technology stocks over the past month represents a rotational correction rather than a big top in the stock market, Bank of America said in a note on Monday. The bank is taking its cues from the New York Stock Exchange advance-decline line, which remains near record highs. The advance-decline line measures the difference of stocks that are moving higher or lower on a daily basis.

title: US benchmarks higher at lunch as tech stocks surge
text: 12.30pm: US benchmarks gain ground US benchmarks were ahead at lunch with tech stocks surging as falling bond yields  encouraged investors back to the sector. The Nasdaq surged over 439 points at 13,048, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average added over 298 at 32,101.

title: New stimulus could drive markets to ‘new high' in short term: Portfolio manager Dan Niles
text: Dan Niles, founder and senior portfolio manager for the Satori Fund, says markets will 'potentially get to a new high' in the short term driven by all the new stimulus, but 'inflation going up is going to become a big problem' by mid-2021. Subscribe to Fox Business!

title: Emerging Markets to Benefit From U.S. Infrastructure Plan, Mobius Says
text: Mar.09 -- Mark Mobius, founder of Mobius Capital Partners, says emerging markets would benefit from a U.S. infrastructure plan. He also says the dollar probably won't get any weaker from here.

title: Yes, Buy This Dip
text: It's been several weeks since I wrote about "bubbles" developing in various sectors. Despite an S&P 500 correction of only around 6%, many areas in the market declined by 30% or more during the recent meltdown.

title: Recoveries Are Rarely Straight Lines
text: The consensus has been disturbed by inflation fears, raising worries about tighter monetary policy, higher bond yields and the interest rate sensitivity of equity markets. When the primary cause of equity market volatility is rising rates, the traditional portfolio diversifiers, government bonds, are unlikely to offer protection.

title: U.S. Small Business Optimism Rises
text: Mar.09 -- Bank of America's Head of Small Business Sharon Miller speaks with Bloomberg's Alix Steel and Guy Johnson about growing optimism for U.S. small businesses as uncertainty dropped to a 10-month low on "Bloomberg Markets:".

title: Panic-like buying signs emerge in Nasdaq after index posts first 10% correction since September
text: Trading in the Nasdaq Composite was exhibiting panic-like-buying behavior midday Tuesday, a day after the index put in its first correction since September. The Nasdaq Composite was trading 3.5% higher at 13,042, at last check, while the Nasdaq Arms Index, a volume-weighted breadth measure, fell to 0.477.

title: Nasdaq Rebounds as Yields Retreat
text: After weeks of sluggish performances in market indexes — particularly the tech-heavy Nasdaq, which is down more than 10% from record highs set last month — the bulls have once again reclaimed the pre-market. Across the board we're seeing green: the Dow looks to open up 140 points, the S&P 500 is up 40 points and the Nasdaq trades 300 points higher than it did as of last night's close.

title: The coronavirus recession is almost over, Wall Street strategists say
text: One year after the S&P 500 tumbled nearly 8% on COVID-19 fears, experts on Wall Street see the US bearing down on the finish line of the pandemic. Declining case counts, vaccine rollouts, and expectations for new stimulus have lifted spirits in recent weeks. Economists have upgraded growth forecasts and investors continue to shift cash from defensive investments to riskier assets more likely to outperform during a rebound. Major banks' strategists are taking it one step further.
